title: Are Cantonese, Hakka, and Hokkien the same dialects? - Quora

response.answer_text: Appearantly not. Hokkien is actually the language that widely spoken by the People whose origin is from Fujian Province, so in the present days, Most Taiwanese, Hokkien people in Fujian China, Most of Singaporean, Chinese Malaysians are this origin and speak this type of language. Hakka actually is a mixed language, the people are in the shared-terroritory within the side of Guangdong, Jiangxi, Fujian. Hakka resembles to the Gan Language in pronounciation. Cantonese is the language that Cantonese people speak the much, people whose origin from Guangdong and partly Guangxi speak this type of language, like people residing in Guangdong and partly Guangxi, Hong Kong, Macau, older Chinese American and Chinese Canadian, Chinese Australian, Chinese New Zealander, Chinese British. The foreign countries Cantonese immigrate are mostly the English-speaking countries as the five countries I mentioned above which are also members of the Five Eyes. But all three are related languages belong to the Han Family of the Sino-Tibetan family.

I may say no. I speak both Cantonese and Hokkien, but I can only understand a little bit of Hakka , which means we use the similar grammar . Basically, Cantonese, Hakka, and Hokkien are Chinese, but we can speak Mandarin Chinese with the people when travelling to different parts of China. As most of them can understand Mandarin Chinese, you dont need to worry about language issue if you know Mandarin Chinese. In China, Mandarin Chinese is a mainly used language. It’s pretty normal that most of the people from different areas speak Mandarin Chinese their own accents. But Chinese consists of 56 languages/dialects from different Peoples that are from different parts of China.

They are not based on their iso. You can check their iso in the following link, if they are with the same langauge iso code, then quite likely they have different iso code. Ethnologue: Languages of the WorldHowever, based on non-Chinese using people’s opinion they may consider them as same language according to their opinion, especially if they are using the two writing system(traditional/simplified) by the users choices. The grammar and vocab of the writing would mostly mandarin based. Thus, the speakers of dialects may using the same writing style depends on whether the readers using the same dialects or not.

Absolutely not - they originate from different parts of China. Cantonese originates from Guangdong province in China, while Hokkien originates from Fujian province and Hakka from Northern/Central China (before migrating to Southeast China). They all have many differences in pronunciation, grammar and even writing (I know for a fact that Cantonese has some dialect-specific characters, not too certain about Hokkien/Hakka but if they did I wouldn’t be surprised).
No, but they are all dialects from south china
